channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Argentina, and Latin America, Mourn Maradona as a Man of the People
item.description: Known for siding with leftist leaders and causes, the soccer legend’s life, and his politics, never strayed far from his impoverished roots, and his fans loved him for it.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi and Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fans revered Mr.Maradona for his prowess with the ball, but they loved him for remaining relatable, a man of the people despite his fame.

item.title: ‘The Crown’ Stokes an Uproar Over Fact vs. Entertainment
item.description: Dramatic liberties in the latest season of the Netflix series, covering the turbulent 1980s, are annoying Britons who wrote of that period, even among those who disparage the royals.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Gillian Anderson as Margaret Thatcher and Stephen Boxer as her husband, Denis, in “The Crown.”

item.title: E.U. Border Agency Accused of Covering Up Migrant Pushback in Greece
item.description: Frontex is under fire for letting Greece illegally repel migrants as the agency expands to play a more central role at the bloc’s external borders.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Migrants arriving on the Greek island of Lesbos in February. The Greek Coast Guard has rescued thousands of asylum seekers over the years but has become much more aggressive this year.

item.title: England’s Lockdown Will Lift, but Many Pub Doors Will Stay Closed
item.description: Some Conservative lawmakers are calling Boris Johnson’s plans to continue restricting most of England’s bars and restaurants “authoritarian.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Closed pubs and clubs in the historic Cavern Quarter in Liverpool, England, last month.

item.title: Turkey Jails Hundreds for Life Over 2016 Coup Attempt
item.description: Those accused of being ringleaders were among the many sentenced in one of the most important mass trials relating to the plot.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Turkish police officers patrolling outside the court near Ankara where the trial of hundreds of people accused of involvement in a 2016 coup attempt took place on Thursday.

item.title: Ethiopia’s Leader Escalates Assault on Tigray Region, Putting Civilians at Risk
item.description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed said that a deadline for the region’s dissident leaders to surrender had lapsed. The conflict threatens to destabilize the entire Horn of Africa.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Refugees who fled the conflict in the Tigray region of Ethiopia receiving aid at a camp in eastern Sudan on Tuesday.

item.title: Venezuela Raids Food Charity, Interrupting Meals for Children
item.description: The charity, Feed the Solidarity, often provides the only meals children receive each day. The government accuses it of subversion, with no evidence.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children in Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, eating lunch last year at a soup kitchen sponsored by Feed the Solidarity.

item.title: Paolo Gabriele, Pope’s Butler in ‘Vatileaks’ Scandal, Dies at 54
item.description: He admitted to stealing files and giving them to a journalist as a way to expose Vatican corruption and protect his boss, Benedict XVI.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Paolo Gabriele, foreground, riding with Pope Benedict XVI in a papal car in 2006. He said he had stolen Vatican documents to expose corruption in the Holy See in the belief that the pontiff was unaware of what was going on around him.

item.title: Video of Police Beating Black Man in Paris Fuels Debate on Filming Officers
item.description: Footage from security cameras and bystanders suggested the officers had lied about the beating, bolstering critics of a new bill that would restrict circulating videos of security forces.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A protest in Paris last week against a security bill that would restrict filming the police, a step civic groups consider a shield for brutality.

item.title: Diego Maradona Is Mourned in Argentina
item.description: For many Argentines, Diego Maradona, who died on Wednesday, was no mere soccer superstar. “I feel like a member of my family just died,” said one.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial for Diego Maradona in the San Telmo neighborhood in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Cho Joo-bin Gets 40 Years in South Korean Prison for Sexual Exploitation
item.description: Cho Joo-bin was convicted of blackmailing young women into making sexually explicit video clips that he sold online.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: After Cho Joo-bin, center, was arrested in March, he told reporters, “Thank you for stopping my life as a devil that I could not stop.”

item.title: Saudi Activist Who Fought For Women’s Right to Drive Is Sent to Terrorism Court
item.description: Loujain al-Hathloul, one of Saudi Arabia’s most prominent prisoners, has been accused of harming the kingdom’s security. Rights groups consider the prosecution a sham.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Loujain al-Hathloul, in an image taken from social media.

item.title: Amnesia Grips a Bosnian Spa That Served as a Rape Camp
item.description: A forest health resort promotes its therapeutic waters and fine dining but bristles with anger at any mention of its gruesome past.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Vilina Vlas (Visegrad, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Hotel)
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The third floor at the Vilina Vlas spa in Visegrad, Bosnia and Herzegovina.

item.title: Wedding Rings Lost in Shipwreck Will Be Returned to Migrant Couple
item.description: The owners of the two rings, which were found in a backpack in the Mediterranean, survived the capsizing of their vessel as they crossed from Libya to Europe.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The wedding rings engraved with hearts and the names Doudou and Ahmed that rescuers found in a backpack floating in the Mediterranean this month.

item.title: Halima Aden Quits Fashion, For Now
item.description: The well-known model shared via Instagram that she’s taking a break to set some boundaries in the industry.
item.dc:creator: Danya Issawi
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Halima Aden at a New York Fashion Week party in Sept. 2019.

item.title: Delta Announces ‘Quarantine Free’ Flights from Atlanta to Rome.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Curtis Compton/Atlanta Journal-Constitution, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Delta Airlines will begin offering “quarantine free” flights between Atlanta and Rome starting next month.

item.title: South Korea reports its biggest one-day jump in cases in eight months.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Wearing face masks in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday. The latest surge in infections started this month, spreading through smaller clusters across the country.

item.title: Merkel outlines Germany’s plan to extend restrictions through December.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing at the window of a doctor’s office in Berlin last week. Germany is tightening a national lockdown amid an increasing level of cases.

item.title: New Jersey’s governor wants schools open. Local officials have other ideas.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.media:description: About 60 students and parents from Scotch Plains-Fanwood School District in New Jersey protested last week after the superintendent announced schools would remain closed until Jan. 19.

item.title: As N.F.L. crowds decline, the Dallas Cowboys keep the gates open.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson
item.media:description: The state of Texas limits attendance at AT&T Stadium, the home of the Dallas Cowboys, to half its capacity of over 100,000. The team plays the Washington Football Team on Thursday.

item.title: Supreme Court blocks New York’s virus-imposed limits to religious services.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A parishioner at a church in the Bronx in May. In some areas of New York, virus restrictions had limited religious services to no more than 10 people.

item.title: Times readers shared what they’re thankful for in six words.
Gratitude in Six Words, From Our Readers
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A mother and daughter hugged on Memorial Day weekend in Wantagh, N.Y.

item.title: Maradona, Covid-19, Macron: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times

item.title: Sewage may offer early signs of coronavirus outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Kim Tingley
item.media:credit: Uli Seit for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sewage treatment plant in Nassau County, N.Y.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Americans have agonized over their Thanksgiving plans, all while coronavirus cases and deaths skyrocket around them.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: C.I.A. Officer Is Killed in Somalia
item.description: The officer’s combat death came as President Trump considers pulling back on American operations in the region.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Adam Goldman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Shabab, the Qaeda-affiliated terror group based in Somalia, remains a deadly threat.

item.title: Hawaii’s Fresh Water Leaks to the Ocean Through Underground Rivers
item.description: If the water could be pumped to the surface, it could help alleviate shortages on the island.
item.dc:creator: Matt Kaplan
item.media:description: Deep underneath Mount Hualalai on Hawaii’s Big Island flow underground rivers of fresh water.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The U.S., breaking virus records, heads into busiest travel season.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Will Dudding
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nurse collects personal information before administering a COVID test at a drive through testing location in Los Angeles.

item.title: Macron’s Rightward Tilt in France Sows Wider Alarm
item.description: One bill would reach into Muslim life, and another would place new restrictions on filming of police. Critics say they’re part of a drift toward repressive government policies.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: A protest in Paris last week against a security bill that would restrict filming of the police, a step civic groups consider a shield for brutality.

item.title: Nick Saban, Alabama’s coach, tests positive.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:description: Nick Saban earlier this year. The coach tested positive for the virus, the University of Alabama said on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Frees British-Australian Scholar in Prisoner Swap
item.description: Iranian state media said the scholar, Kylie Moore-Gilbert, was released in return for three Iranians. Social media identified the Iranians as men detained in Thailand on bomb plot charges.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: The Modern Middle East, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A still image from a video of Kylie Moore-Gilbert in 2017. The British-Australian scholar was serving a ten-year sentence in Iran’s notorious Evin prison.

item.title: France Drops Rape Investigation of Former Deputy Mayor of Paris
item.description: Prosecutors said the case was closed because the statute of limitations on the alleged offense had expired.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Former Paris Deputy Mayor, Christophe Girard, has been a power broker in politics and culture for a generation.

item.title: Post-Brexit Border Test Leads to 5-Mile Traffic Jam in Southern England
item.description: French border officials were holding a trial run of immigration procedures that could come into effect if Britain and the European Union don’t reach a trade deal by the end of December.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Gareth Fuller/Press Association, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Trucks lined up in Kent, England, waiting to enter the Eurotunnel terminal.

item.title: The C.D.C. is considering shortening its recommended quarantine period.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: A student in the Ohio State dorm designated for those in quarantine, in Columbus, Ohio, this month.

item.title: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Shares Her Miscarriage Grief
item.description: She wrote that she held “an almost unbearable grief, experienced by many but talked about by few.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, wrote that she felt “something was not right” the morning she suffered a miscarriage.

item.title: Cyclone Nivar Threatens India's Puducherry
item.description: The severe storm weakened after making landfall near Puducherry. At least 3 people were killed.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Heavy rains in Chennai, India, as Cyclone Nivar approached on Wednesday.

item.title: Ditching the Turkey: Thanksgiving Memories (and Misadventures) of Reporters Abroad
item.description: Some of our international journalists have gone to great lengths trying to bring a taste of home to their new locations. But it hasn’t always worked out.
item.dc:creator: Mark Shimabukuro
item.media:description: Vivian Yee’s Thanksgiving dinner in Beirut last year: two turkeys, 11 nationalities and 30 people.

item.title: Golf or green spaces? A debate in Australia intensifies after pandemic lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: A U.S. record: Two weeks, two million virus cases.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Leatherby

item.title: Biden and China
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Joe Biden with Xi Jinping in Beijing in 2011.

item.title: Pennsylvania bans alcohol sales on one of the busiest nights of the year.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: The night before Thanksgiving is usually a busy one in Pennsylvania’s drinking spots, but they will have to stop serving at 5 p.m. this year, the state has ordered.

item.title: A Feared Law to Protect the Monarchy Returns Amid Thailand’s Protests
item.description: The country’s lèse-majesté law, which makes insulting the king punishable by years in prison, is being used against the protesters’ leadership for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Bangkok on Wednesday. Antigovernment protests have brought thousands of Thai people onto the streets since July.

item.title: Driver Crashes Car Into Gate Outside Angela Merkel’s Office
item.description: The motive is unclear, and the police said Germany’s chancellor was never in danger.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A message on the car that crashed near the office of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Wednesday read, “You damned murderers of children and old people.”

item.title: Handcuffed by the police at 11, a girl in Michigan has died of the virus at 14.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Rifkin

item.title: May Madness? Postponing the tournament is possible as college basketball begins.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:description: Cal State Fullerton coach Dedrique Taylor, here with his players in 2018, has put the season on hold as the team quarantines after a player tested positive.

item.title: Casualties From Banned Cluster Bombs Nearly Doubled in 2019, Mostly in Syria
item.description: The war in Syria, which began almost a decade ago, makes it the only country where the outlawed bombs have been repeatedly used since 2012.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Hamza Adnan/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A child receiving medical treatment after a Syrian government cluster-bomb strike outside Damascus in 2016.

item.title: A Chinese firm seeks permission to market a vaccine before it has completed trials.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Elsie Chen
item.media:description: A convention center in Manama, Bahrain, was used for a large-scale trial of a Sinopharm coronavirus vaccine in August.

item.title: Fatal Shark Attacks in Australia Jump, Raising Questions
item.description: Eight people have been fatally attacked this year, the most in nearly a century. But scientists say these numbers don’t tell the full story.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: Flowers tied to a handrail at a memorial for a surfer who died after being bitten by a shark at Greenmount Beach in Coolangatta, Australia, in September.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: France and Germany tussle over defense policy.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Trump at the NATO leaders’ summit last December.

item.title: U.N. Gets OK to Aid Crippled Yemen Tanker After Months of Waiting
item.description: Officials have been waiting since July to inspect and repair the FSO Safer, a stricken tanker off the Yemen coast. Houthi rebels have finally given approval, the U.N. said.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: The FSO Safer, moored off Yemen’s coast, in a satellite image taken in June.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: With the transition underway, President-elect Joe Biden can plan his pandemic response.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Priscilla Jana, Lawyer Who Battled Apartheid, Is Dead at 76
item.description: Representing Nelson and Winnie Mandela among many others, Ms. Jana fought for equality in South Africa both in and out of the courtroom.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Paul Faith/PA Wire, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Priscilla Jana speaking in Belfast, Northern Ireland, in 2007, when she was South Africa’s ambassador to Ireland. After many years as an anti-apartheid lawyer, she became a lawmaker and then a diplomat when the African National Congress took power in 1994.

item.title: Donors Pledge Less Aid to Afghanistan During a Violent Chapter
item.description: Intense violence, including a deadly market bombing on Tuesday in one of the few remaining Afghan havens, Bamiyan, has Afghan officials pleading for continued assistance.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage
item.media:description: An Afghan security officer at the site of two blasts at a market on Tuesday in the city of Bamiyan.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Lessons from South Korea’s vaccine campaign.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Dani Blum
item.media:description: A patient getting an influenza vaccine in Seoul, South Korea, in October.

item.title: Scotland Is 1st Nation to Make Period Products Free
item.description: The Scottish Parliament voted unanimously to pass a measure that makes free period products available to anyone who needs them, the first country to do so.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Sanitary products for sale at a supermarket in Perthshire, Scotland.

item.title: In the first distribution push, 6.4 million doses of Pfizer’s vaccine will be shipped across the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Vials of coronavirus vaccine candidate BNT162b2 are inspected at a Pfizer manufacturing site in Kalamazoo, Mich.

item.title: Outcry in France After Police Clear Paris Migrant Camp
item.description: With Parliament considering a security bill, officers used tear gas and dispersal grenades in their response to a camp set up in a prominent square to protest against a lack of housing.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A migrant camp in central Paris on Monday.

item.title: Russian Vaccine Maker Sputnik V Reports Positive Results on Incomplete Trial
item.description: The results were based on an unspecified small group of volunteers during the ongoing Phase 3 trial of the vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A volunteer received a trial coronavirus vaccine at a clinic in Moscow in September.

item.title: Appeal in Lockerbie Bombing Reaches Scotland’s Highest Court
item.description: The family of Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, the only person convicted in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jetliner that killed 270 people, is seeking to clear his name, although he died in 2012.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The wreckage of Pan Am Flight 103 near Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988. A total of 270 people were killed after a bomb exploded onboard.

item.title: A Coronavirus Vaccine Game Plan, With Help From South Korea
item.description: Officials and scientists fought misinformation with data and clear communication — offering a game plan for the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Denise Grady
item.media:description: A patient getting an influenza vaccine in Seoul, South Korea, in October.
